text:
I have a test plan with 2 thread groups. The second group must start after 
ramp-up of 10 sec.

For convenience, I decided to define a shortcut on my desktop that starts 
Jmeter with my test plan already loaded. Suprisingly all my assertions broke 
when I ran the test, although it is a well-tested system. Then I noticed that 
Jmeter started the second thread group right away without observing the ramp-
up time.

I was even more surprised to see that it does not happen when I start Jmeter 
without -t as I used to. 

This is a reproducible bug.

Regards,
-Gera
creator: gera@shegalov.com
sebb@apache.org
text:
Ramp-up time has no effect on when a thread group starts; it only determines how
long it takes to start all the threads in a thread group.

Please can you explain exactly how you have set up your test; ideally with a
very simple test plan that shows the problem.

(In reply to comment #1)
> Ramp-up time has no effect on when a thread group starts; it only determines 
how
> long it takes to start all the threads in a thread group.
> Please can you explain exactly how you have set up your test; ideally with a
> very simple test plan that shows the problem.

This bug can be dropped. The coincidence of my plan working properly and 
using -t made me thought it is a bug. In reality, the feature I was looking 
for is a "startup delay" in the ThreadsGroup Scheduler configuration. 

Sorry for bothering you.
creator: gera@shegalov.com

text:
By the way, the Test Plan has a startup delay field. This applies to all 
thread groups.
creator: sebb@apache.org
